description:
Soup, a single syllable denoting the very simplest foods and surely one of the oldest ways of serving. The British seem to have an almost religious belief in its powers to steady, strengthen and fortify. We love it rough and rustic with big chunks of veg and frozen fingers cupped around the steaming bowl. Yet it can also come limpid clear and jewel-like as a sophisticated consomme. As sales of soup in the UK continue to soar the famous and fashionable are souping to get skinny. The soup maker is the countertop gadget at the moment. And even simple stock has been reinvented as bone broth, soup with supposedly transformative powers. Soup is evidently a complex business. People have strong feelings about it.

Not always a pauper's meal. For discerning palates, the Guinness World Record for the most expensive bowl of soup is 108 pounds for a meat-and-fish dish called Buddha Jumps Over the Wall, which has to be ordered in advance. But not every soup experience is pleasant.
Worst garlic in France. Absolutely unbelievable.
We were invited back and the person had onion and garlic and water. I couldn't get it down.
